Connected to http://localhost:8086 version 1.7.10
InfluxDB shell version: 1.7.10
> äº¤äº’é¢æ¿æ‰§è¡Œå‘½ä»¤

Creating Databases and Users in InfluxDB

Create database: create database jmeter_t2 View databases Switch database: use jmeter_t2 Create user “admin” with password ‘admin’ with all privileges View users

> show users
user  admin
----  -----
admin true

If the user permission admin is displayed as true, the database preparation is complete

Grafana

When writing test cases, I realized that the chart display isn’t really necessary. The tps data for the interface can already be observed when executed in the command line; mostly, I just want to know the internal execution time of the program.

The document also describes how to customize listeners

Afterword

  • High-performance programming inherently relies on a single loop thread; any locks, queuing for entry, and queuing for exit will cause unnecessary performance loss
  • The time spent on core business logic is greater than the time spent introducing other code; concurrency can effectively improve efficiency, and if the core processing time is sufficiently small, it’s best to be cautious when introducing other code

item.title: Building computers
item.description:
The author was fascinated by assembling computers from a young age and began learning about hardware assembly after starting university. They recommended websites for comparing hardware performance and provided purchasing suggestions, including CPU, solid-state drives, mechanical hard drives, and memory frequency. They also shared their experience and precautions regarding hardware selection.

Destiny, beyond words

Ever since I was little, I wanted to build my own computer, but the economic conditions just wouldn’t allow it. It wasnâ€™t until college that I finally had the chance, and for portability reasons, I got a laptop. If you want a specific time frame, when did I start wanting to build a computer? It all started at the library back home. It was a pretty decent-sized library for a city district â€“ it had an electronic reading room (though I never went, as it charged by the hour) and a magazine reading room. Thatâ€™s where I stumbled upon magazines like â€œå¤§ä¼—è½¯ä»¶â€ (Popular Software) and â€œç”µè„‘æŠ¥â€ (Computer News). For someone with limited exposure to computers, they were essentially divine educational resources. Seeing chapters about raiding dungeons made me want to build my own computer so I could pull mobs and be a main damage dealer; seeing the “black technology” sparked fantasies of recreating what was described in the books (a discussion on using hacking tools). Though high school coursework was demanding, with my limited knowledge at the time, I felt I needed to both study and play. It was a pretty carefree time. Iâ€™d often use going to the library as an excuse, grabbing a small bag and strolling over there. The city wasn’t that big, so I usually walked. Once inside, Iâ€™d enjoy the air conditioning while reading novels, comics, and gaming magazines, occasionally glancing at some serious books.

As you get older, it’s easy to forget things. This isn’t the first time something like this has happened at the library. When I was in junior high school, my relatives assembled a computer, and I donâ€™t remember why they built that machine back then. The operating system was Windows 2003, and the games included the card game and Age of Empires. I spent all sorts of time trying to sneak the keys and play games with my cousin.

Entering junior high, the school offered basic computer training. Later, when I transferred schools, I was also introduced to the concept of computer competitions. By the time I reached high school, I participated in NOIP once. Speaking of this, it’s impossible not to mention the power of alumni â€“ the high schoolâ€™s computer building was funded by alumni donations and included a computer lab and library. It was actually during the initial wave of China’s internet boom at that time. School leaders also supported participation in computer competitions; after all, several seniors from the previous two years had been admitted to key universities through computer-related programs.

I’ve never looked back at my relationship with computers like this before. No wonder I made such a complete shift from the automation major to the computer industry after graduation â€“ the seeds were already sown, though those involved didnâ€™t realize it. Having been exposed to them since childhood, I thought I was quite knowledgeable, but in reality, I only understood the basics. My biggest advantage was that initial passion.

Hardware assembly

Browse Carrefour, Chiphell, and Zhihu’s computer building sections; a beginner can relatively easily create a list of the machine they need. When purchasing a CPU after 2019, if your financial situation isnâ€™t abundant, AMD is the best choice for higher performance.

Here’s a translation of the provided Chinese text: I recommend a commonly used hardware performance comparison website: https://cpu.userbenchmark.com/, which is comparable to Xianyu (é—²é±¼) for pricing. True experts can find great deals on used items on Xianyu, saving a lot of money. If you’re not very knowledgeable, I donâ€™t recommend using it; I bought fake memory there myself. Although it seems to be working fine so far, Iâ€™m not entirely sure, and the model and parameters are completely mismatched.

SN550 VS SN750

The difference between the SN550 1TB and the SN750 1TB is that their sustained read/write speeds differ by a factor of two â€“ one reaches 850MB, the other 1.6GB. However, there’s no noticeable difference in daily use because both have the same 4K performance. Of course, this refers to the 1TB capacity SN550; the 500GB and 250GB versions have slower sequential read/write speeds. Honestly, unless youâ€™re not worried about cost, the SN550 is fine for everyday use. The main reason I didn’t buy it isn’t its sequential read/write speed, but rather that it only comes in a maximum of 1TB capacity, while the SN750 offers 2TB. For me, the value lies more in having an extra M.2 NVMe slot on my motherboard than in the price difference between these SSDs, without needing to expand further.

Based on the consensus of online users, purchasing an adapter board will allow a B150 motherboard to support an M.2 SSD

Choosing a Mechanical Hard Drive

Currently, mechanical hard drives are priced stably. For users with large storage needs, it is recommended to select a suitable mechanical hard drive. Frequent downloaders are advised to consider enterprise-grade hard drives, such as:

  • Western Digital Gold
  • Seagate Exos

It’s recommended to partition large-capacity mechanical hard drives. Frequent download operations should be directed to a specific partition. If bad sectors appear later, they can be concentrated in one partition, and that partition can then be discarded, effectively extending the lifespan of the mechanical hard drive.

Seagate Official Introduction

Overview of Seagate Enterprise Hard Drives

Overview of Seagate Enterprise Hard Drives

Memory frequency

Starting from the perspective of daily work, frequency will not have a significant impact on performance

Memory Timing Memory (Salted Fish Memory)

Memory timings (or RAM timings) are four parameters describing the performance of synchronous dynamic random-access memory (SDRAM): CL, TRCD, TRP, and TRAS, measured in clock cycles. They are typically written as four numbers separated by hyphens, such as 7-8-8-24. The fourth parameter (RAS) is often omitted, and a fifth parameter may be added: Command rate, usually 2T or 1T, also written as 2N or 1N. These parameters specify latency times that affect random access memory speed. Lower numbers generally indicate faster performance. The ultimate element determining system performance is the actual latency time, typically measured in nanoseconds.

When converting memory timings to actual delays, it’s most important to note that they are measured in clock cycles. Without knowing the duration of a clock cycle, itâ€™s impossible to determine if one set of numbers is faster than another.

For example, the clock frequency of DDR3-2000 memory is 1000 MHz, and its clock cycle is 1 ns. Based on this 1 ns clock, a CL=7 results in an absolute latency of 7 ns. Faster DDR3-2666 (clocking at 1333 MHz with a 0.75 ns cycle) may use a larger CL=9, but still produce a shorter absolute latency of 6.75 ns.

Modern DIMMs include a serial presence detect (SPD) ROM chip, which contains memory timings recommended for automatic configuration. The PC’s BIOS may allow users to adjust these timings to improve performance (with the risk of reducing stability), or in some cases increase stability (such as using the recommended timings).

Note: Memory bandwidth measures memory throughput and is typically limited by transfer rate rather than latency. It is possible to continuously transmit at peak rates by interleaving access to multiple internal banks of SDRAM. Bandwidth can be increased at the expense of increased latency. Specifically, each new generation of DDR memory has a higher transfer rate, but absolute latency does not change significantly, especially for the first batch of products in a new generation, which often have longer latencies than the previous generation.

Even with increased memory latency, increasing memory bandwidth can improve the performance of computer systems with multiple processors or multiple execution threads. Higher bandwidth will also enhance the performance of integrated graphics cards without dedicated video memory.

item.title: Website acceleration and domain settings
item.description:
Due to slow access to GitHub Pages within China, the author applied for a personal domain name and purchased CDN acceleration services from a domestic cloud hosting provider. During the configuration process, the author encountered an issue where the www subdomain was inaccessible. The problem was eventually resolved by deleting the wildcard domain resolution and setting up the second-level domain separately. The author also shared the principles and configuration experience of CDN acceleration, as well as the attempts and lessons learned from using Nginx reverse proxy.

Background

The website is hosted on GitHub Pages, and due to some well-known reasons, accessing GitHub Pages from within China can be slow. Therefore, I applied for a personal domain name and purchased CDN acceleration services from a domestic cloud hosting provider. When setting up the acceleration service, I remembered that I had a development machine with Docker, frp, k8s, and other services deployed, all of which have corresponding dashboards. Following the principle of not wasting resources, I configured several reverse proxies and linked them to subdomains.

When I was happily using my second-level domain, I suddenly found that the www subdomain was inaccessible. In Alibaba Cloud, DNS was configured to resolve simultaneously to both www.xiangtianlong.com and xiangtianlong.com. When CDN acceleration had not been enabled yet, both domains worked normally.

When configuring CDN acceleration, due to having too many subdomains, a wildcard domain rule was enabled, routing everything to the development machine. This resulted in the www subdomain also going down. Yes, you read that right, www is a subdomain. The actual website is deployed on GitHub Pages, and the development machine has no cached web content.

Regarding why the site wasn’t deployed on the development machine, itâ€™s because itâ€™s a static blog and paired with GitHub Actions, which automatically integrates and publishes â€“ itâ€™s really great

Domain name

Non-professional web development doesn’t involve SEO or cross-domain issues when it comes to understanding domain names. For a blog site, using a bare domain can highlight the bloggerâ€™s siteâ€”this refers to people like me who use Chinese pinyin as their domain nameâ€”and with most access now being mobile, it allows for fewer characters to be entered.

The desktop version allows you to skip typing www and com using keyboard shortcuts

CDN

I’ve used both Aliyun and Tencent Cloud, itâ€™s not difficult for new users to get started. Tencent Cloud even has a video explaining the related concepts. The principle of CDN acceleration is the same as that of JD’s warehouse: when launching new products, they are pre-distributed to warehouses across the country, and when a delivery request is triggered, they are distributed from the nearest location.

Return address: The original address where website resources were stored

Cache file settings, browser F12, management console, simple analysis of static and dynamic resources

  • All 0 days validity
  • 0-day validity for .php, .jsp, .asp, .aspx
  • .jpg, .png, .js, .css, .woff2 1-day validity

Tencent Cloud Configuration Rules:

  • Cache expiration rules can be configured up to 10 entries
  • The priority among multiple cache expiration rules is bottom-up
  • The cache expiration time can be set up to a maximum of 365 days

A Lamentable Confession

I hadn’t used Nginx before, and I thought I could understand the configuration of reverse proxy by simply searching online. But it was a bit confusing, and after fiddling with it for half a day, I couldn’t even figure out a 302 redirect. It was useless. So I decided to try a simple approach: deleting the wildcard domain resolution mode and setting up each second-level domain independently. Thatâ€™s when I suddenly noticed that Alibaba Cloud DNS had a feature called “Display URL Jump,” and after trying it, it turned out to be exactly what I wanted â€“ a 302 redirect.

I got the first secondary domain working fine, but when I tried to set up the second one, it didn’t work. I was almost starting to doubt myself. Then suddenly it started working after a while. It seems like Aliyunâ€™s DNS propagation occasionally glitches out.

item.title: Blog IDE environment and random thoughts
item.description:
This article introduces the basic concepts of Markdown and its applications in various software. It recommends using VSCode as an IDE and lists recommended plugins. The author shares their experience switching from Hexo to Hugo, emphasizing Hugo’s flexibility and customization capabilities. Finally, it provides some tips for quickly getting started with new technologies and shares a trick for resolving the issue of Hugo theme styles not updating.

Preface

Markdown

A lightweight markup language that allows people to write documents in a readable and writable plain text format

Detailed Markdown syntax will not be elaborated on in this article; a recommended ebook is available, click here

Many software on the market already support md as a writing format. The CSDN blog system launched an online editor that supports md syntax, and it comes with an introductory article about md syntax when you use it for the first time, which I think is pretty good; Evernote added support for md notes in 2018, with various md tag options in the quick bar, making it feel similar to editing regular articles, and the overall interactive process is friendly to beginners.

IDE recommendations

When writing this article, it’s already 2020. You must have heard of VS Code, after all, anyone who considers using Git Page to build a blog system is an industry professional. In earlier years, Sublime and Atom were also good choices. With two years of community support, VS Code has developed rapidly and gradually become the preferred entry point for beginners.

The relationship between Microsoft and the open-source community has transitioned from a state of separation to a honeymoon period: embracing open source. The company I work for has also actively introduced the Java ecosystem in recent years; in other words, the Java ecosystem is genuinely appealing for business development within China now.

VS Code extension recommendations

Plugin List

Plugins all have their own Readme files, introducing basic usage and core features; some plugin authors also provide dynamic effect demonstration images

It’s very convenient to introduce images using the image plugin method of Hugo

I haven’t memorized the shortcuts, so I opened the VS Code shortcut management menu and searched for “md,” looking at it several times; I reviewed the plugin usage instructions again

hugo

As a writer, I’ve switched from Hexo to Hugo. My nature is to tinker and I simply couldnâ€™t stand writing articles quietly without constantly experimenting.

  1. Hugo supports placing images and md documents in separate folders
  2. Academic themes support various types of article styles in design
  3. Various convenient custom extensions

academic

The website defaults to exampleSite, menu integration uses the #component method, and using url is recommended

The URL pattern allows for single-page jumps when clicking on navigation, rather than scrolling on the homepageâ€”this is purely a matter of personal preference

  • Styles: Essays, Speeches, E-books
  • Flexibility: Customize overall style, customize CSS styles

This theme’s support for Chinese is not yet very complete, mainly from a visual perspective â€“ the font size isn’t quite in line with Chinese reading habits. However, Hexoâ€™s developers are mostly Chinese, which gives it an advantage over Hugo in this regard.

However, it’s about doing things yourself and providing for your own needs. Inspect the browser elements. Once youâ€™ve located the element, to know the CSS style name that needs modification, click Insert Style Rule Below in the sidebar. Even with deeply nested CSS, you can easily get the node name.

  • Introducing custom.css
  • Introducing custom_js
  • The theme’s built-in syntax highlighting settings, official link

Conclusion

The little one is about to complain again â€“ why are you being so vague from beginning to end, not mentioning any details?

What I want to say is, these things will be enough for you

  • Official manual
  • Plugin Description

To quickly get started with new technologies, it’s recommended to first read the official documentation. Donâ€™t worry about understanding everything on the first pass; at least get a general idea. Search engine results may not always be consistent with the latest version and could potentially mislead you. The same applies to reading new books â€“ look at the table of contents first to understand what the author intends to cover. Sometimes, reading the preface is helpful; in some foreign works translated into Chinese, the translator’s preface often summarizes the bookâ€™s content and core ideas.

Easter egg

Switching to the built-in Hugo Academic style didn’t change the appearance when published to the site. Clever users probably already figured it out: clear your local browser cache, and the problem is solved. The ingenious me: F12 developer mode, switch to network, check disable cache, refresh, done!

item.title: Automatic system switchover
item.description:
Automatically deploy a Hugo blog to GitHub Pages and Gitee using GitHub Actions

Background introduction

While updating my blog yesterday, I discovered that the Travis service was unavailable. Checking the Travis webpage, I saw that the progress was stuck on pulling the source code. Suddenly, I remembered the action service recently launched by GitHub.

Given that it will be quite busy and requires an application to use action, now that it has officially launched, and with free time this weekend, why not try out a new toy?

You can find all official documents on the website, so I won’t reproduce them here. If youâ€™ve used Kubernetes before, youâ€™ll notice that the YAML configuration for actions is very similar to it.

For introductory tutorials or Chinese language resources, I recommend searching é˜®ä¸€å³°’s blog. There are two articles: the first is an introduction to basic grammar, and the second is a practical case study.

Main body

Required knowledge points

  • github secrets
  • action grammar

The core job is completed using existing components, pushed to domestic Gitee using commands. The command part is quite rough, all force pushes, and inherits the logic used with Travis.

name: github pages and gitee pages

on:
  push:
    branches:
      - hugo

jobs:
  deploy:
    runs-on: ubuntu-18.04
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v2
        with:
          submodules: true

      - name: Setup Hugo
        uses: peaceiris/actions-hugo@v2
        with:
          hugo-version: 'latest'
          extended: true

      - name: Build Github and Gitee ## å•ä¸ªstepåªèƒ½å†™ä¸€ä¸ªrunå‘½ä»¤
        run: hugo -b "https://www.xiangtianlong.com/" -d "github_public" && hugo -b "https://www.xiangtianlong.com/" -d "gitee_public" && ls

      - name: Deploy Github
        uses: peaceiris/actions-gh-pages@v3
        with:
          github_token: ${{ secrets.BLOG_TOKEN }}
          publish_dir: ./github_public
          publish_branch: master
          cname: xiangtianlong.com

      - name: Deploy Gitee
        run: cd ./gitee_public && git init && git config user.name "TianlongXiang" && git config user.email "tianlongxiang51@gmail.com" && git add . && git commit -m "Update TianlongXiang's Blog" && git push --force "https://xiangtianlong:${{ secrets.GITEE_PASSWORD }}@gitee.com/xiangtianlong/xiangtianlong.git" master:master

Afterword

Based on the actions provided by the official market, there are quite a few supported features currently available, and after building a Docker image, you no longer need to rely on services provided by Docker Hub

I checked Hugo’s issues and found that when using GitHub Actions to automatically deploy Git Pages, the final published webpage needs to be on the master branch. If deployed to other branches, GitHub will display a message indicating that there are syntax problems with the deployment webpage in the settings interface.

In reality, it’s because Hugo’s source files are located in the master branch, and GitHub is treating them as the source code for the Jelly blog, leading to errors that prevent checking and passing

The solution is also simple: put the Hugo source files on another branch and publish the static files on the master branch

item.title: Allocator for standard library containers
item.description:
Custom allocators can improve performance, increase memory efficiency, and solve problems related to frequent small memory allocations

Cause

Recently, I’ve been working on network packet development and frequently need to allocate and release small blocks of memory. I initially thought about using a memory pool, but after reviewing several existing ones, I found this

https://github.com/cacay/MemoryPool

Seeing the interface, I was a bit puzzled â€“ the implementation of this memory pool seems a little strange. The MemoryPool’s implementation logic allocates fixed-size memory spaces. Having looked at the boost memory pool interface, it provides a template that is instantiated when used. Fortunately, there are already articles introducing this library, mentioning the concept of allocator.

wiki

In C++ programming, an allocator (in English: allocator) is an important component of the C++ standard library. The C++ library defines various data structures collectively referred to as “containers” (such as linked lists, sets, etc.), and a common feature of these containers is that their size can change at runtime; to achieve this, dynamic memory allocation becomes particularly necessary, and allocators are used to handle the container’s memory allocation and release requests. In other words, an allocator encapsulates the low-level details of memory management for Standard Template Library (STL) containers. By default, the C++ standard library uses its own built-in general allocator, but according to specific needs, programmers can also customize allocators to replace it.

The allocator was originally invented by Alexander Stepanov as part of the C++ Standard Template Library (STL), with the initial goal of creating a way to “make the library more flexible and independent of the underlying data model,” allowing programmers to utilize custom pointer and reference types within the library; however, when incorporating the Standard Template Library into the C++ standard, the C++ Standards Committee realized that complete abstraction of the data model would result in unacceptable performance losses. As a compromise, the restrictions on allocators in the standard became stricter, and as a result, the current standard describes allocators with significantly less customizability than Stepanov originally envisioned.

Although there are limitations on allocator customization, custom allocators are often necessary in many cases, typically to encapsulate access methods for different types of memory spaces (such as shared memory and recycled memory) or to improve performance when using memory pools for memory allocation. In addition, introducing a dedicated custom allocator in programs that frequently allocate small amounts of memory can also be greatly beneficial from the perspectives of memory usage and runtime.

Requirements

One of the primary reasons for defining custom allocators is to improve performance. Utilizing a dedicated custom allocator can enhance program performance, or increase memory efficiency, or both [4][8]. The default allocator allocates storage space using the new operator, which is often implemented using C language heap allocation functions (malloc()) [Wen 5]. Because heap allocation functions are often optimized for occasional large memory allocations, the default allocator generally performs well when allocating memory for containers that require a large amount of memory to be allocated at once (such as vectors and double-ended queues) [8]. However, for associative containers and doubly linked lists, which require frequent allocation of small amounts of memory, using the default allocator can often result in low efficiency [4][9]. In addition, malloc()-based default allocators have many problems, such as poor locality of reference [4] and potential memory fragmentation [4][9].

In short, this section (â€¦â€¦) is like a “I Have a Dream” speech for this standard regarding allocators. Before the dream comes true, programmers concerned with portability will limit themselves to stateless custom allocators. â€”â€”Scott Meyers, ã€ŠEffective STLã€‹ In light of this, in such situations, memory pool allocators are often used to address the problem of frequent small allocations [8]. Unlike the default “on-demand allocation” approach, when using a memory pool allocator, the program pre-allocates a large block of memory (the “memory pool”), and then, when memory is requested, the custom allocator simply returns a pointer to memory within the pool; during object destruction, no actual deallocation is required, but it is delayed until the end of the memory pool’s lifecycle [Note 1][8].

The topic of “custom allocators” has seen considerable discussion among C++ experts and authors, such as Scott Meyers’ work “Effective STL” and Andrei Alexandrescu’s “Modern C++ Design.” Meyers observed that if you require all instances of an allocator for a given type T to be equal, then the allocator instances must not contain state. Although the C++ standard encourages library implementers to support allocators with state [Reference 4], Meyers calls this related passage a â€œseemingly wonderful ideaâ€ but also almost empty talk, and he considers the restriction on allocators “too strict” [4]. For example, STL’s list allows the splice method, where nodes of one list object A can be directly moved into another list object B, which requires that the memory allocated by Aâ€™s allocator can be released by Bâ€™s allocator, thus inferring that the allocator instances of A and B must be equal. Meyers concludes that allocators are best defined as types using static methods. For example, according to the C++ standard, an allocator must provide an other class template that implements the rebind method.

Additionally, in “The C++ Programming Language,” Bjarne Stroustrup argues that â€œ‘strictly limiting the allocator to avoid different object information’ is clearly not a big dealâ€ (in essence) and points out that most allocators do not need state, and performance may even be better in the absence of state. He proposes three use cases for custom allocators: memory pool-based allocators, shared memory allocators, and garbage collection allocators, and demonstrates an implementation of an allocator that utilizes an internal memory pool to quickly allocate/deallocate small amounts of memory. However, he also mentions that such optimization may already be implemented in the sample allocator he provides [3].

Another use of a custom allocator is debugging memory-related errors [10]. To do this, you can write an allocator that allocates extra memory when allocating, and use it to store debug information. This type of allocator not only ensures that memory is allocated/deallocated by the same allocator, but also protects the program from cache overflows to a certain extent [11].
